q1.value: Effect of expressive feature and sex on implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts

q3.value: It has been demonstrated that people, especially female, showed negative implicit attitudes about math according to the meta-analysis.  While there's also evidence that implicit attitudes are not unconscious and that external material (such as storylines) can change implicit attitudes. So I'm interested in whether changing the expressive feature of mathematical content can have an impact on people's implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. art. Therefore, I will add a new variable "expressive feature" to design a new research to study implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, besides the variable "sex".

q4.value:
H1. Sex will affect implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, female will show more bias against mathematics.  (Revalidation of the original conclusion)
H2. Expressive feature will affect implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, if the material expresses mathematical content in artistic form, participants will show less negative implicit attitudes about mathematics after reading it.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A 2x2(sex: male,female; expressive feature: express mathematical content in artistic form, express mathematical content in mathematical form) mixed design. Sex is the between subject variable, and expressive feature is the within subject variable.

q9.value: In order to avoid the possible sequence effect, I will perform a simple randomization process on the reading order of the material.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited on WeChat. Participants will be paid ¥20 for agreeing to participate. Participants will be students in Fudan University.

q13.value: My target sample size is 30 participants. I will attempt to recruit up to 50, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q15.value: I will make experiment appointments by week on the preceding Saturday and count the number of participants timely. If the total number of participants(all the participants who have completed the experiment and participants scheduled for next week) on that Saturday is up to 50, I will suspend recruitment and appointment.

question.value: I will manipulate the "expressive feature" variable. It has two levels: express mathematical content in artistic form(To show the application of a mathematical principle in graphics in the form of drawing), and express mathematical content in mathematical form(To show this same mathematical principle in formula form). In the background information section, the introduction to the mathematical principle will be the same.
I will use repeated measures ANOVA to test each hypothesis. The main effects and interaction of two independent variables "sex" and  "expressive feature" will be examined.

q21.value: I will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA results are statistically significant.

q22.value: If a subject was very careless during the experiment, his/her data will be excluded.

q23.value: If the subject didn't complete the experiment from the beginning to the end as required, that subject will be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value: I expect that major may be related to implicit attitude about mathematics vs. arts, since my target participants are college students. Therefore, I will look for relationships between major and implicit attitude about mathematics vs. arts. Maybe it can be a moderator or something.

registration_responses.q3: It has been demonstrated that people, especially female, showed negative implicit attitudes about math according to the meta-analysis.  While there's also evidence that implicit attitudes are not unconscious and that external material (such as storylines) can change implicit attitudes. So I'm interested in whether changing the expressive feature of mathematical content can have an impact on people's implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. art. Therefore, I will add a new variable "expressive feature" to design a new research to study implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, besides the variable "sex".

H1. Sex will affect implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, female will show more bias against mathematics.  (Revalidation of the original conclusion)
H2. Expressive feature will affect implicit attitudes about mathematics vs. arts, if the material expresses mathematical content in artistic form, participants will show less negative implicit attitudes about mathematics after reading it.

This detailed plan can be viewed in the supplemental file.

attributes.title: Orthopaedic implant allergy - the role of patch testing

q1.value: Metal sensitivity in patients with orthopedic implants: a systematic review protocol on the role of patch-testing

q3.value: Cutaneous and systemic hypersensitivity reactions to metallic implants are broadly described in the literature. The risk of developing metal hypersensitivity is higher post-operatively, therefore it’s advised to preoperatively patch-test in patients with previous signs and symptoms of allergy. However, the role of metal allergy in implant patients remains controversial and no consensus has yet been reached as to whether and when a patch-testing is advisable. Arguably because determining the clinical relevance of a positive test in these patients’ proofs to be a challenge. We aim to determine the role of preoperative and postoperative patch-tests by reviewing the literature on allergic reactions to metal orthopedic implants in which clinical relevance of patch-tests can be determined.

q4.value:
- Do patients with a metal allergy (pre-implantation) confirmed by patch-test have a higher risk of developing post-operative complaints after being implanted with an implant containing the metal for which they are allergic, compared to patients who are (pre-implantation) not allergic for the implanted metals.  
- Can a patch-test be used in the work-up of patients with post-operative (implant) complains, and when should it be used?
- What is the prevalence op implant allergy in patients with unclassified post-operative symptoms?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: The titles and abstracts of studies retrieved from the search strategy will be screened by two independent reviewers to assess potential eligibility for the review (on the basis of the outlined inclusion criteria). The full text of these articles will be retrieved and assessed by these two reviewers to confirm they meet the outlined inclusion criteria. Any disagreements will be discussed and resolved by consensus. Risk of bias will be assessed by the primary reviewer, and thereafter also assessed by a second reviewer. Any discrepancies will be discussed, and resolved by consensus. Risk of bias will be assessed by the primary reviewer, and thereafter also assessed by a second reviewer. Any discrepancies will be discussed, and resolved by consensus.

question.value: A pre-determined form will be used by the primary reviewer to extract data from included studies. The primary reviewer will complete data extraction.
No manipulation of variables

Extracted information will include: study type, study population, participant demographics, sample size, gender, prevalence statistics, implant type, symptoms, onset of symptoms, allergens, revision or removal of the implant and outcome.

Provided the data is sufficiently homogenous a random-effects meta-analysis will be used to synthesize the data quantitatively. For the question of risk two, we do not anticipate sufficient homogeneity for quantitative synthesis. If this is the case, results will be tabulated and briefly synthesized narratively.  The quality of evidence, strength of recommendations and risk of bias will be assessed on the study level using the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE) approach. The quality of evidence for randomized controlled trials and observational studies is judged on a scale from very low (+1) to high (+4).

Arguably because determining the clinical relevance of a positive test in these patients’ proofs to be a challenge. We aim to determine the role of preoperative and postoperative patch-tests by reviewing the literature on allergic reactions to metal orthopedic implants in which clinical relevance of patch-tests can be determined.

uploader.file_name: Systematic Review of Prehospital Case Reports Protocol Registration.pdf

q2.value: Lea-Sophie Kinkel, Rabia Er, Melina Jonischkeit, Sophia Elisabeth Wagner, Marie Hennecke

q3.value:
This is a class project at the University of Siegen.
There is evidence suggesting that approach and avoidance goal orientations have an effect on affective feelings, satisfaction and commitment in a romantic relationship. This effect has not been studied in the causal direction of the affective feelings influencing the approach and avoidance goal orientations. Therefore, we want to examine the temporary effects of positive/negative affect on the approach and avoidance goal orientations regarding the participants current romantic relationships.

q4.value: If affective feelings affect approach and avoidance goal orientation in romantic relationships,  positive mood will positively affect the approach goal, whereas negative mood will positively affect the avoidance goal.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (mood) and 3 levels (positive mood, negative mood, control group without mood induction). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the program "Sona" that the University of Siegen uses. Students of psychology have access to it and will be rewarded with course credit worth half an hour. We will also collect data through emails to people we personally know and by face to face communication. Participants who are not students of psychology will not be rewarded. All subjects must be 18 or older and must have Internet access to answer the questions of the questionnaire.

q13.value: The target sample size of our study is 330 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 350, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: We used the software program G*power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a small to moderate effect size of .30 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: On the 31th of March 2020, the survey will be closed.

question.value: We will manipulate participants' mood by having them listen to a music piece (positive mood: Happy African Village - John Bartmann; negative mood: Serial Killer - John Bartmann) while they are  vividly remembering an either positive or negative event from their own past. Participants in the control group will not listen to any music and will be asked to describe a daily event instead.

We will measure approach and avoidance motivation after the mood manipulation. We will measure it with the German version of the Impett-Scale (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'not agree at all', 7 being 'totally agree').
We will also measure participants´commitment to their relationships with the "Investment Model-Scale" by Rusbult. Here, we will just measure commitment level, leaving out satisfaction level, quality of alternatives and Investment size.

First of all, we will use the PANAS to check whether our mood manipulation (positive/negative) was effective. Whether the  experimental groups (positive/negative mood) differ significantly from our control group with regard to their positive and negative affect, will be determined with two separate univariate between-subjects ANOVAs and subsequent post-hoc tests by Dunnett. The ANOVA tests will help us determine any significant differences in the means across of positive and negative affect all three experimental conditions. The post-hoc tests by Dunnett will determine if both experimental groups differ significantly from the control group.

For our hypothesis check, we will use two separate univariate between-subjects ANOVAs to determine any significant differences in the means of approach and avoidance goal orientations across the three different experimental conditions again. This will show us, if there is a significant effect of our mood manipulations on the approach and avoidance goal orientations regarding the relationships of the participants.
To determine whether the positive mood condition and the negative mood condition both differ significantly from the control condition with regard to their average approach and avoidance orientation, we will use post-hoc tests by Dunnett. This test will help us to determine, whether the means of the experimental groups differ from the mean of the control group significantly.

In an explorative manner we will examine, if different relationships and their duration have an effect on the approach avoidance goal orientations.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete more than 75% of the questions, that participant will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: At the beginning of the study we will measure the level of commitment of each participant to their partner. We want to explore the effects of the commitment on approach and avoidance goal orientations.

There is evidence suggesting that approach and avoidance goal orientations have an effect on affective feelings, satisfaction and commitment in a romantic relationship. This effect has not been studied in the causal direction of the affective feelings influencing the approach and avoidance goal orientations. Therefore, we want to examine the temporary effects of positive/negative affect on the approach and avoidance goal orientations regarding the participants current romantic relationships.

attributes.title: Perceptions of Pete Buttigieg at a Christian university in his home state
attributes.description: This experiment compares the implicit attitudes of white evangelical college students toward Pete Buttigieg when they are informed or not informed that he is gay.

q1.value: Perceptions of Pete Buttigieg by Evangelical Students in Indiana

q3.value:
The purpose of the study is assess the degree to which knowledge of Pete Buttigieg's sexual preference influences perceptions of his competence. Like Pete Buttigieg, participants in this study are young, white, Christians from Indiana. Many of these participants are not politically engaged or aware of who Pete Buttigieg is. This lack of background knowledge makes it possible to test the degree to which Buttigieg's sexual preference influences both implicit and explicit attitudes towards him by evangelical voters, who based on similarity should be mostly inclined to vote for him.
Participants enrolled at a small Christian university in Indiana will be recruited via email to participate in an experiment. In both conditions, participants receive a short biography of Pete Buttigieg, including a picture. In the experimental condition, participants are also informed that Pete Buttigieg is gay. Next, all participants complete reading comprehension questions to ensure that they read the biography. Then all participants complete an IAT using pictures of Pete Buttigieg and other similar white males. Pictures are categorized as "Pete Buttigieg" or "not Pete Buttigieg" and words are categorized as competence or incompetence related. After completing the IAT participants are asked to rate their willingness to vote for Buttigieg, their previous knowledge of Buttigieg, their political affiliation, their attitudes towards the LGBTQ+ community, and their gender.

q4.value: Participants with no previous knowledge of Pete Buttigieg will view his equally positively in the condition where his sexual preference is not included compared to the one where his sexual preference is included.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Participants receive an email inviting them to participate in an experiment on political attitudes by clicking on a link.
All participants sign the online consent form
In both conditions, participants read a short bio of Pete Buttigieg.
The control condition ends with the statement, "If elected he would be the youngest President in US history." The experimental condition ends with the statement, "If elected he would be the youngest President in US history and the first who is openly gay."
All participants complete an implicit attitude measure (IAT) using photos of Pete Buttigieg and photos of several other similar white males. Participants categorize the photes as "Pete Buttigieg" or "Not Pete Buttigieg." The words categorized in the IAT are related to competence/incompetence.
After completing the IAT, all participants rate their willingngess to vote for Pete Buttigieg on a scale from 1 (not at all willing) to 7 (extremely willing). Next, they are asked to rate how much they knew about Pete Buttigieg before the experiment on a scale from 1 (none at all) to 5 (a great deal). Then on the next screen participants are asked to describe their political affiliation on a scale from 1(extremely conservative) to 7(extremely liberal), and to rate their feelings towards the LGBTQ+ community on a scale from 1(extremely negative) to 7(extremely positive). Finally participants are ask to indicate gender.

q9.value: Participants with last names in the first half of the alphabet will be placed in condition one; participants with last names in the second half of the alphabet will be placed in condition two.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants who are enrolled in a course in the behavioral sciences (criminal justice, sociology, social work, addictions counseling, psychology) will receive an email inviting them to participate in an experiment regarding attitudes toward a political candidate by clicking on a link. They will not receive any compensation. By clicking on the link, students will complete the experiment in qualtrics, where the data will be stored. Emails will be sent on Friday, Feb. 21. Follow up emails to encourage participation will be sent again on Monday Feb. 24. Data collection will end on Feb. 28.

q13.value: Emails will be sent to approximately 500 students. I am not sure what the response rate will be in this case.

q14.value: The sample size was chosen based on convenience/access to student email.

q15.value: I will stop data collection on Feb. 28.

question.value:
Knowledge of Pete Buttigieg's sexual preference will be manipulated.
In both conditions, participants read a short bio of Pete Buttigieg.
The control condition ends with the statement, "If elected he would be the youngest President in US history." The experimental condition ends with the statement, "If elected he would be the youngest President in US history and the first who is openly gay."

1. IAT ratings of Pete Buttigieg's competence
2. Willingness to vote for Pete Buttigieg on a scale from 1(not at all willing) to 7 (extremely willing)

A simple independent t-test will be used to compare the two conditions' IAT scores and willingness to vote. A second analysis controlling for previous knowledge of Pete Buttigieg will also be run on both dependent variables. I may also run linear regression results

q21.value: I will run two-tailed tests and if there is a p value of less than .05, I will infer that there is a difference in attitude towards Pete Buttigieg between the two conditions.

q22.value: I may run results including only participants who do not have previous knowledge of Pete Buttigieg separately from participants who have previous knowledge of him.

q23.value: I will not include participants who do not include the entire experiment.

registration_responses.q1: Perceptions of Pete Buttigieg by Evangelical Students in Indiana
registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of the study is assess the degree to which knowledge of Pete Buttigieg's sexual preference influences perceptions of his competence. Like Pete Buttigieg, participants in this study are young, white, Christians from Indiana. Many of these participants are not politically engaged or aware of who Pete Buttigieg is. This lack of background knowledge makes it possible to test the degree to which Buttigieg's sexual preference influences both implicit and explicit attitudes towards him by evangelical voters, who based on similarity should be mostly inclined to vote for him.
Participants enrolled at a small Christian university in Indiana will be recruited via email to participate in an experiment. In both conditions, participants receive a short biography of Pete Buttigieg, including a picture. In the experimental condition, participants are also informed that Pete Buttigieg is gay. Next, all participants complete reading comprehension questions to ensure that they read the biography. Then all participants complete an IAT using pictures of Pete Buttigieg and other similar white males. Pictures are categorized as "Pete Buttigieg" or "not Pete Buttigieg" and words are categorized as competence or incompetence related. After completing the IAT participants are asked to rate their willingness to vote for Buttigieg, their previous knowledge of Buttigieg, their political affiliation, their attitudes towards the LGBTQ+ community, and their gender.
registration_responses.q4: Participants with no previous knowledge of Pete Buttigieg will view his equally positively in the condition where his sexual preference is not included compared to the one where his sexual preference is included.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants with last names in the first half of the alphabet will be placed in condition one; participants with last names in the second half of the alphabet will be placed in condition two.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data

registration_responses.q14: The sample size was chosen based on convenience/access to student email.
registration_responses.q15: I will stop data collection on Feb. 28.
registration_responses.q21: I will run two-tailed tests and if there is a p value of less than .05, I will infer that there is a difference in attitude towards Pete Buttigieg between the two conditions.
registration_responses.q22: I may run results including only participants who do not have previous knowledge of Pete Buttigieg separately from participants who have previous knowledge of him.
registration_responses.q23: I will not include participants who do not include the entire experiment.

attributes.title: Interventions influencing the dietary consumption of animal-based products: An overview of reviews
attributes.description:
Review question(s)
1) What interventions influence the dietary consumption of animal-based products?
  1a) What does the combined information from all systematic reviews indicate?
  1b) How well do current systematic reviews use best-practice approaches?
  1c) What gaps exist in the review-level literature?

summary.value: This registration serves as an a priori research protocol for an overview of reviews investigating interventions to reduce animal consumption.

data.name: Reducing animal consumption - overview of reviews protocol.pdf

extra.selectedFileName: Reducing animal consumption - overview of reviews protocol.pdf
